Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial support for U.S. participation in the Young Topologists Meeting 2019, held at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Lausanne (EPFL) in Switzerland, July 22-26, 2019. The Young Topologists Meeting (YTM) is an annual European conference which focuses on the work of graduate students and early career researchers in topology that brings together participants from all over the world. At the YTM, junior topologists present their work to a large international audience and also attend mini-courses taught by senior topologists. The conference provides opportunities for the participants to meet new colleagues and mentors, to form research collaborations, and to learn about current developments in the field. Its open and supportive atmosphere encourages early career mathematicians, including those from underrepresented groups, to pursue research careers in topology.

The YTM is an annual event, first started in 2007, which traditionally alternates between Copenhagen, Denmark and Lausanne, Switzerland (with an exception in 2017 when it was held in Stockholm, Sweden). The conference features parallel sessions of contributed talks by graduate students and early career researchers covering a broad spectrum of topics in topology. In addition to these talks, there will be mini-courses by two senior topologists on two current threads of research in pure and applied topology. This year, Julie Bergner (University of Virginia) will give a mini-course on the homotopical notion of 2-Segal spaces, while Vidit Nanda (University of Oxford) will give a mini-course on topological data analysis. More details are available on the conference web page: https://ytm2019.epfl.ch/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Young Topologists Meeting (YTM) is an annual European conference for graduate students and junior researchers in topology that brings together over 150 participants from all over the world.

It is the largest conference worldwide dedicated to graduate students and junior researchers in topology. It provides a unique opportunity for junior topologists to gain experience presenting their scientific work, learn about new subjects through accessible talks aimed at junior researchers, broaden their awareness of what's going on in topology, and meet a community of researchers that they will interact with for the rest of their professional lives. For US graduate students, the YTM facilitates the creation of (potentially lifelong) connections and collaborations with their peers in Europe and around the world.

This grant from the NSF supported the participation by US-based graduate students in the 2019 YTM which was held at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne, Switzerland from July 22 to July 26, 2019. This year there were a total of 157 participants from 97 institutions in 29 countries. Included among these were 26 participants from 21 US institutions in 17 states, many of whom were supported by the NSF.

The heart of the conference was 48 talks by conference participants about their mathematical research. These talks covered a broad range of topics within pure and applied topology. In addition, two plenary speakers, Julie Bergner (University of Virginia) and Vidit Nanda (University of Oxford), gave 4-lecture minicourses. The work of 26 additional researchers was also presented in a poster session.

The YTM continues to be a success. It offers junior topologists the opportunity to present their work to a large audience, often for the first time; facilitates the dissemination of new work in topology to the next generation of researchers; and encourages new collaborations and mathematical partnerships. It plays a significant role in developing a feeling of community and belonging among the next generation of researchers in the field of topology.
